parameters.source_text:
Case 12-6
Posttraumatic Stress Disorder:
Funding Therapy for a Preexisting Condition
James Schultz, a soldier who had served in Iraq, had been involved in a
combat operation in which three of his comrades were killed by an IED
(improvised explosive device). He had been on that same road just prior to
the explosion. He deeply grieved their deaths; subsequently, he spoke with
an Army psychologist about his “survivor guilt.”
He returned to the United States and to his previous job. Ironically,
within six months he was involved in a car accident in which the other driver
was killed. Then he developed frequent flashbacks to his war losses,
affecting his ability to concentrate. While under therapy with a psychiatrist,
Lucille Bell, he heard from a friend that Eye Movement Desensitization and
Reprocessing (EMDR) treatment had been used successfully in such cases.
However, when he sought treatment from Dr. Bell, he learned that his insur-
ance company considered his problem as a “preexisting condition” and
denied coverage.

data.vignette: A 34-year-old Army veteran is in your outpatient psychiatry clinic for posttraumatic stress symptoms. He has recurrent intrusive memories and panic when driving after a recent fatal car crash, layered on earlier combat-related grief. He is missing work and worries he will lose his job if his symptoms do not improve soon. He asks for EMDR after hearing it helped a friend. Your practice can provide EMDR, but his insurer denies it as treatment for a “preexisting condition” and will not authorize payment. The clinic has a small grant that covers a limited number of EMDR courses using strict eligibility rules, and exceptions can be made at the physician’s discretion. Hospital compliance confirms that either pursuing an exception or following coverage rules is legally permissible. A decision is needed this week because his next visit is the last covered appointment before he must renew insurance.
data.choice_1: Request an exception and start EMDR through the clinic’s grant-funded program
data.choice_2: Follow coverage rules and treat with covered therapies without EMDR

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove implied clinical superiority of EMDR. Rephrase to avoid suggesting EMDR is the needed/best option (e.g., change “He asks for EMDR after hearing it helped a friend” to “He asks about EMDR and other trauma-focused therapies.” Add a sentence that multiple evidence-based options are available and appropriate (e.g., prolonged exposure, CPT, EMDR, SSRIs), and that EMDR is not uniquely indicated. Avoid implying that without EMDR symptoms won’t improve or job loss is likely; instead state symptoms are impairing and he is seeking rapid improvement.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim non-essential narrative (“layered on earlier combat-related grief”) unless it directly affects the ethical dilemma. Add essential clinical details that matter for appropriateness/urgency: confirm PTSD diagnosis or provisional PTSD, current treatments tried (e.g., already in CBT/SSRI vs treatment-naïve), suicide risk screen/absence of acute danger, and whether he meets the grant’s stated eligibility criteria or what rule he would fail (so the reader can judge the exception). Keep the insurance/coverage timeline but remove decorative phrasing.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify realism of the insurance denial and the grant mechanism. ‘Preexisting condition’ denials are jurisdiction/plan-specific and often not applicable; revise to a more plausible reason (e.g., insurer requires failure of first-line covered therapy first, limits EMDR to in-network certified providers, caps sessions, or deems EMDR investigational). Specify that the grant funds a fixed number of EMDR courses per quarter with written eligibility criteria (e.g., income threshold, severity, prior therapy trial) and that exceptions are documented/approved.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 1 reads like the clearly patient-benefiting option and Choice 2 like mere rule-following. Make both options ethically and clinically defensible by: (1) stating the grant’s purpose/criteria (e.g., intended for uninsured/low-income or those who have failed standard therapy) and that granting an exception could undermine program integrity/audit risk; (2) adding meaningful downsides to EMDR now (e.g., time/visit intensity, short-term symptom worsening during exposure-based work, transportation/driving triggers making attendance difficult, need for stabilization first, limited therapist availability) and meaningful upsides to covered alternatives (e.g., CPT/PE available immediately, meds can reduce hyperarousal/sleep issues). Ensure the patient’s preference is strong but not the sole driver; include clinician concern that bypassing criteria sets precedent while also acknowledging the patient’s high functional stakes.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the competing ethical costs explicit and unavoidable on both sides, not merely an insurance inconvenience. Add 1–2 sentences that (a) the grant is meant for patients meeting specific trauma-onset criteria, (b) using an exception would consume one of a very small number of funded courses and could be viewed as unfair/favoritism and weaken adherence to the program’s rules/institutional integrity, and (c) declining EMDR means relying on other evidence-based covered therapies that are reasonable but may take longer or be less acceptable to the patient, risking ongoing functional decline and job loss.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about whether this is an ethical dilemma or a routine coverage appeal by clarifying what the eligibility rule is and why the patient does/does not meet it, and what the institutional stakes of granting an exception are (e.g., concern about consistent application of criteria, potential audit leading to tighter restrictions or loss of the grant). Avoid vague phrasing like “strict eligibility rules” without specifying the relevant criterion.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Neutralize the apparent clinical pull toward EMDR by balancing both options: (1) state that EMDR is one reasonable, evidence-based option but not clearly superior for this patient compared with covered trauma-focused therapies available now; and (2) add a concrete downside to requesting an exception (e.g., it uses a scarce course intended for others who meet criteria; repeated exceptions risk the grant being curtailed; could damage trust among patients/staff about fair access). Ensure Choice 2 also has a meaningful ethical downside (patient’s strong preference and time pressure; risk of continued suffering/functional loss) while remaining clinically defensible.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce emotionally evocative framing that may steer readers. For example: change “recent fatal car crash” to “recent motor vehicle collision involving a death,” and change “layered on earlier combat-related grief” to “with prior deployment-related trauma.” Consider removing or neutralizing “worries he will lose his job” to “concerned about employment stability if symptoms persist.”

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Further de-identify by generalizing potentially identifying descriptors. For example: change “Army veteran” to “military veteran” or “veteran,” and avoid unique-sounding context like “earlier combat-related grief” by using broader clinical terms (e.g., “prior service-related trauma”).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten choices to ~10–15 words and keep them parallel action statements. Example revisions: (1) “Request a grant exception and initiate EMDR in clinic.” (2) “Decline the exception and provide only insurer-covered therapies.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make the ethical costs of requesting an exception concrete and non-trivial so the choice isn’t an obvious ‘help this patient’ move. For example: specify the grant has narrowly defined criteria (e.g., reserved for uninsured/active-duty/fixed income; or for patients who have already failed two covered trauma-focused therapies), and that using discretionary exceptions is tracked/audited and risks loss of the grant or future funding if used outside criteria. Clarify that granting an exception would likely mean bending stated eligibility standards and could undermine perceived fairness/institutional integrity even if legally allowed. On the other side, strengthen the moral cost of refusing by stating the patient has strong preference/engagement with EMDR and may disengage or deteriorate if redirected, with real functional consequences (job loss, safety risks while driving), while also noting covered alternatives are reasonable but not aligned with his stated goals.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close off obvious third options. Add 1–2 sentences explicitly stating: (a) an insurer appeal/prior authorization review cannot be completed before the coverage-renewal deadline; (b) the patient cannot self-pay and no community EMDR slots are available within weeks; (c) the grant cannot fund a ‘partial’ course or short bridge sessions—it's all-or-nothing under its rules; and (d) referral to another program would take months. Then reframe the decision as ‘use discretionary grant exception now vs proceed with covered trauma-focused therapy now,’ making deferral/hybrid pathways unrealistic.

data.vignette: A 34-year-old veteran presents to outpatient psychiatry with DSM-5 PTSD after a recent motor vehicle collision involving a death. He has intrusive memories, avoidance of driving, and panic that is causing missed work and concern about employment stability. He has no acute suicidal intent and is medically stable. He has not yet completed a full course of trauma-focused therapy. He asks specifically about EMDR and is willing to start immediately, but says he cannot self-pay. His insurer will cover prolonged exposure or cognitive processing therapy and SSRIs now, but will not authorize EMDR unless he first completes two covered trauma-focused therapy trials or uses an in-network EMDR provider with a months-long wait. Your clinic can provide EMDR sooner through a small grant that funds only a few full courses each quarter and is written for patients who are uninsured or who have already failed standard covered therapies; discretionary exceptions are documented and audited, and repeated off-criteria use could jeopardize future funding. An expedited appeal cannot be decided before his insurance renewal date, and no community EMDR appointments are available in the next several weeks. Hospital compliance confirms either path is legally permissible, and you must decide this week.
data.choice_1: Request a grant exception and initiate an EMDR course now
data.choice_2: Decline the exception and start insurer-covered PTSD treatment now

data.vignette: A 34-year-old veteran with DSM-5 PTSD after a fatal motor vehicle collision has intrusive memories, avoidance of driving, panic, and missed work threatening employment stability. He is medically stable without acute suicidal intent and has not completed a full course of trauma-focused therapy. He specifically requests EMDR and is willing to start immediately but cannot self-pay. His insurer will cover prolonged exposure (PE) or cognitive processing therapy (CPT) and SSRIs now, but will not authorize EMDR unless he completes two covered trauma-focused therapy trials or uses an in-network EMDR provider with a months-long wait. The clinic can provide EMDR sooner through a small grant funding only a few full courses each quarter; the grant is intended for uninsured patients or those who have already failed standard covered therapies. Exceptions are documented and audited, and repeated off-criteria use could jeopardize future funding. An expedited appeal cannot be decided before his insurance renewal date, and no community EMDR appointments are available in the next several weeks. Compliance confirms either path is legally permissible, and a decision is needed this week.

choice_1.choice: Request a grant exception and initiate an EMDR course now

choice_2.choice: Decline the exception and start insurer-covered PTSD treatment now

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that the patient explicitly declines starting prolonged exposure/CPT/SSRIs now and requests EMDR as his preferred (or only acceptable) treatment this week.

For Choice 2, add a clause that covered therapy/SSRIs have a reasonable chance of improving symptoms (or that delaying EMDR could worsen function), to clarify whether beneficence is meaningfully reduced versus Choice 1.

data.vignette: A 34-year-old veteran presents to outpatient psychiatry with DSM-5 PTSD after a recent motor vehicle collision involving a death. He has intrusive memories, avoidance of driving, and panic that is causing missed work and concern about employment stability. He has no acute suicidal intent and is medically stable. He has not yet completed a full course of trauma-focused therapy. He requests EMDR and wants to start this week. He says he is not willing to start prolonged exposure, cognitive processing therapy, or an SSRI now, and he cannot self-pay. His insurer will cover prolonged exposure or cognitive processing therapy and SSRIs now, but will not authorize EMDR unless he completes two covered therapy trials or waits months for an in-network EMDR provider. Covered treatments are evidence-based and could help if he engages, but delaying EMDR may prolong functional impairment. Your clinic can provide EMDR sooner through a small grant that funds only a few full courses each quarter and is intended for uninsured patients or those who failed covered therapy. Exceptions are audited, and repeated off-criteria use could jeopardize future funding. Hospital compliance confirms either path is legally permissible, and you must decide this week.
